p: This special issue of PLOS Medicine brings together the latest research across many of these health risk pathways, as well as highlighting at-risk populations, such as women [ 3], children [ 4], and small island populations [ 5]. New findings indicate that heat waves can affect cognitive abilities [ 6], rainfall extremes could increase sewage contamination in cities [ 7], warmer temperatures produce hazardous ozone air pollution [ 8], and wildfires, as occurred recently in California, have substantial adverse consequences for human health [ 9]. Some surprising findings from research studies have also emerged: countering the perceived potential benefit of carbon dioxide (CO 2) emissions on plant growth and food security [ 10], CO 2-induced nutritional deficiencies have been highlighted [ 11].
